description:
In post-WWII Japan, Prof. Shikishima has built up Shikishima Industries to be a technological powerhouse, working on developing robots. However, at the heart of their success lurks a dark secret from the war, something that cost the life of Prof. Kaneda, the mentor of Prof. Shikishima. Now Kaneda's son, Shoutarou, is about to learn the truth, and it will change him forever.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

node.description:
[Official Website](https://yokoyama-mitsuteru.com/)

Mitsuteru Yokoyama was a Japanese manga artist born in Suma Ward of Kobe City in Hyōgo Prefecture.
Yokoyama spent his boyhood during World War II and was evacuated to Tottori with his family. He graduated from Kobe municipal Ota junior high school and went on to the Kobe municipal Suma high school. [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/Osamu-Tezuka)'s "Metropolis" made a deep impression on Yokoyama who wished to become a manga artist in earnest and so he contributed his works to a comic book in his high school days.
Yokoyama came out with the book "Otonashi no Ken (音無しの剣 Sword without sound)" for his manga artist début, which caught [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/Osamu-Tezuka)'s attention.
Created the very first "Giant Robot" series, Tetsujin 28 (Gigantor) in 1956. Also created the first "Magical Girl" series, Sally the Witch, in 1966.

Died from a house fire in 2004, aged 69.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1219713270149341184)

Originating from Studio Comet, where he initially worked as a production assistant. He is friends with, and often collaborates with [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) and both [You](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/) and [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). All three of them worked at Gainax together in the '90s.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1219713270149341184)

Originating from Studio Comet, where he initially worked as a production assistant. He is friends with, and often collaborates with [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) and both [You](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/) and [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). All three of them worked at Gainax together in the '90s.

Akira Senjuu debuted in the music industry in 1992, by composing the soundtrack for "Mama wa Shougaku Yonensei" anime. He then expanded his work into J-Dramas and movies. In 2001 his music arrangement for J-Drama "Strawberry on the Shortcake"  won in "Best Music Arrangement" nomination of 28th Television Drama Academy Awards.    In anime Industry he is best known for composing the score for Mobile Suit Victory Gundam.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉成曜) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoh_Yoshinari) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yoh_yoshinari)

A Japanese animator, director and storyboard artist currently working at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/). Yoshinari entered the anime industry through the influence of his older brother, [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). Several of his early works were uncredited second key animation and in-betweens for his brother during high school. After leaving professional school, he applied to [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) and [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Not receiving a response from Gainax, he joined Madhouse. Due to a misunderstanding, Gainax failed to process his application until three months later. Not wanting to explain, Yoshinari told Madhouse; "being an animator is too hard for me," and switched to Gainax.

At Gainax, Yoshinari had joined just after the closure of [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). With nothing to do, he was immediately put onto visual development for the film [Aoki Uru](https://anilist.co/anime/21430/), although the film’s production was later broken off due to the studio’s financial state. Undoubtedly his breakout as an animator was just a few years later when he served as one of the lead animators in [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/). Yoshinari worked at Gainax until leaving for Trigger in 2011, a studio founded by fellow ex-Gainax members, [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/) and [Masahiko Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/108023/). At Trigger he debuted as a director on [Little Witch Academia](https://anilist.co/anime/14349/).

Yoshinari is recognized by the way he represents volume and perspective using spheres, especially for smoke and explosions, as well as his character action in general. His characters often borrow traits from western animation, such as rectangular heads, low contrast shading, big eyes and angular lineart. He uses expertly timed smears, dramatic camerawork, and complicated background animation to convey dynamism. His movement is springy and tense, cleanly situated in the dominant cartoony style of ‘00s Gainax. He remarks [Nijitte Monogatari](https://anilist.co/manga/112385/) as one of his most important influences, with his artistic style particularly visible in his design work for [Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/) and Little Witch Academia.

Also a big fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)’s, having done multiple short [animations](https://anilist.co/anime/123638/) based on his manga characters.

Married to producer [Naoko Tsutsumi](https://anilist.co/staff/150017/).

(Sources: Wikipedia, Anidb, Animators Wiki)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/真木太郎)

Tarou Maki is a producer. He graduated from the Department of Law at Waseda University in 1977 and joined Pioneer. In 1997 he founded production studio [Genco](https://anilist.co/studio/79/) and serves today still as its president.

Oishi worked at Studio Junio at the beginning of his career, and soon after joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/). There he debuted as a key animator on [Mobile Suit Victory Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/89/) in 1993. [Hideyuki Morioka](https://anilist.co/staff/101526/) and [You Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/) were among his co-workers at the studio. In 1994, Oishi got involved on [Yu Yu Hakusho](https://anilist.co/anime/392/) as a key animator and during its production he met [Akiyuki Shinbou](https://anilist.co/staff/100089/), a prolific episode director on the series and a to be long-time colleague and friend of his. Oishi continued working as a freelance animator through the '90s.

In 2001, he made his directorial debut with the 46th episode of [Cyborg 009: The Cyborg Soldier](https://anilist.co/anime/1678/). Soon after this he started getting involved in studio [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/)'s works with aforementioned Shinbou. In 2009, Shinbou and him directed [Bakemonogatari](https://anilist.co/anime/5081/) together, with Oishi serving as the chief director. In 2016, he directed the movie trilogy [Kizumonogatari](https://anilist.co/anime/9260/), which is considered to be his magnum-opus. Oishi usually draws his works' storyboards himself, and is known for taking a long time finishing them. Kizumonogatari's storyboards took him several years to complete.

[Naoyuki Tatsuwa](https://anilist.co/staff/103584/), who has also been involved in many of Shaft's projects, called him the "[Togashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96893/) of Shaft."

In 2016, he directed the movie trilogy [Kizumonogatari](https://anilist.co/anime/9260/), which is considered to be his magnum-opus. Oishi usually draws his works' storyboards himself, and is known for taking a long time finishing them. Kizumonogatari's storyboards took him several years to complete.

[Naoyuki Tatsuwa](https://anilist.co/staff/103584/), who has also been involved in many of Shaft's projects, called him the "[Togashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96893/) of Shaft."

He initially aspired to be a professional mangaka and moved to Tokyo to pursue his dream. In 1971, he joined at Tatsunoko Pro as painter before becoming animator. After leaving the company he went freelance and participated in many works in different roles, ranging from key animator to episode director, before making his proper directorial debut with a short film titled Chicken Man & Red Head, which was a part of the [Robot Carnival](https://anilist.co/anime/2182/) anthology.

Nakamura revolutionized anime in the early '80s with his more realistic, extremely detailed and fluid style of animation. He is one of the few animators who has proven that he can successfully take on almost all of the creative burden on a project, proven in both his Robot Carnival short and episode 4 of [Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/1822/).

His 2001 film, [A Tree of Palme](https://anilist.co/anime/1141/), was an official selection of the Berlin Film Festival.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%9D%92%E6%9C%A8%E6%82%A0%E4%B8%89)

Yuuzou Aoki is a director, animator, screenwriter and storyboard artist.
